I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the Country Program Consultation Mission in December 2005, the Government 
of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to improve efficiency in road transport, energy conservation, and 
environmental protection. TA was included in ADB’s country strategy and program update 
(2006–2008) and was confirmed by the Government during the Country Programming Midterm 
Review  Mission  in  March  2006.  An  ADB  Fact-Finding  Mission  (the  Mission)  reviewed  the 
rationale and justification of the proposed TA for Resource Optimization in the Road Sector with 
the Ministry of Communications (MOC) as the Executing Agency (EA) and the Ministry of 
Finance.  The  Mission  discussed  with  MOC  the  need  to  optimize  the  use  of  land  in  road 
infrastructure development and improve the efficiency of public and freight transport, energy 
efficiency, and environmental protection, and how the proposed TA could help. The Mission 
reached an understanding with the Government on the scope and output of TA, cost estimates, 
a financing plan, consultants’ terms of reference, and implementation arrangements.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Over the last 2 decades, road construction in the PRC has moved at a rapid pace, and 
the development of the expressways and other road networks has contributed greatly to the 
PRC’s economic development. By the end of 2005, the road network had grown to include 
41,000 kilometers (km) of expressways, 38,400 km of class I highways, 246,400 km of class II 
highways, 344,700 km of class III highways, 921,300 km of class IV highways, and 338,800 km 
of rural and other roads, for a network total of 1.93 million km.  
 
3.  Land Use Planning. The land utilized by the road network is estimated at over 23,000 
square km. With the planned increase of the expressway network to 65,000 km and the overall 
road network to 2.3 million km by the end of the 11th Five-Year Plan 2006–2010 (11FYP), the 
projected area of land used for road infrastructure will increase significantly. Conversion of 
farmland  for  infrastructure  development,  industrialization,  and  other  investment  has  been 
needed to support the PRC’s economic growth. Cities offer discounted or free land to attract 
developers or investors to garner the financial gains of development. However, this mechanism 
has distorted land use and brought excessive conversion of farmland, creating a shortage of 
good farmland. Today, the PRC’s farmland per capita is one third of the world average. The 
Ministry of Communications thus faces a challenge in achieving the objectives of the 11FYP 
with limited land resources. 
 
4.  Public and Freight Transport. Rapid economic growth in the PRC has changed the 
structure of urban areas, which contribute 80% of the gross domestic product (GDP). Urban 
areas have been changed not only by economic development but also by migration from rural 
areas. In a single generation, 300–400 million people have shifted from the countryside to the 
city. The urban share of the total population grew from 26% in 1990 to almost 40% in 2005. This 
shift brought suburban development to many cities, making biking and walking less feasible and 
rapidly increasing the number of people who need public transport. In response to this need, the 
development of efficient and affordable public transport is an urgent priority. Rapid economic 
growth also brings increased freight traffic. Logistical costs have been cited as making up about 
30–40% of overall product costs in the PRC, much more than the 5–20% in the United States. 
Freight transport in the PRC heavily relies on expressways, but expanding the expressway 
network is not the only way to increase the efficiency and reliability of freight transport. It is clear 
that efficient and reliable freight transport is required for sustainable development.

2     
5.  Energy Use. In parallel with economic growth, the number of vehicles on roads in the 
PRC has grown rapidly. The number of registered vehicles increased from about 1 million in the 
early 1990s to 32 million in 2004. As a result, fuel consumption was 10 million tons in 2005.  
With development, the PRC has become the world’s second largest oil consumer, changing 
from being an exporter of crude oil to importing a third of its fuel. The number of registered 
vehicles is projected to reach 170 million by 2020 under a business-as-usual scenario, with fuel 
consumption projected to soar to 100 million tons by that year. Long-term energy security is 
becoming a real concern. 
 
6.  Vehicle Emissions. Soaring oil consumption is a matter of the concern not limited to 
energy security but also to the environment. Burning 100 million tons of oil, as projected in 2020, 
will generate 102 million tons of the greenhouse gas (GHG). The National Statistics Bureau 
estimated economic losses to pollution in 2004 at CNY511.8 billion ($63 billion), equivalent to 
3.05% of GDP, with 43% of the loss due to air pollution. The State Environmental Protection 
Administration estimated that auto emissions of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons accounted 
for 79% of total emissions in urban areas nationwide in 2005. This environmental issue is 
relatively new but increasingly urgent.  
 
7.  The Government is keen to move toward a savings-oriented approach to development, 
particularly in the transport sector. The Government is focusing on the three fields: (i) road 
planning  and  land  use,  (ii)  road  transport  management,  and  (iii)  energy  efficiency  and 
environmental protection.  
 
8.  With  regard  to  land  use,  land  resources  have  been  imprudently  used  for  road 
infrastructure development. Because roads have been constructed very rapidly, efficiency of 
land use and other opportunities, e.g., preserving productive farmland, private development, and 
coordination with social activities, were sacrificed for fast development. An additional 24,000 km 
of expressways will be developed by the end of the 11FYP in 2010, as part of a 400,000 km 
expansion of the road network. New frameworks and measures for efficient land use need to be 
established for efficient conversion and use of land to ensure sustainable and well-balanced 
development. 
 
9.  Growing urban populations and urbanization resulting from national economic growth 
are raising demand for public transport and expanding the areas to be served. However, the 
continuing shift to private cars and rapidly worsening road congestion are causing the quality of 
service and efficiency of public transport to deteriorate. In addition, less consideration of mass 
transit systems has been paid in urban road networks. The structure of urban road networks 
and inflexible regulations for public transport make it difficult for public transport operators to 
efficiently  respond  to  increased  demand.  It  is  becoming  clearer  to  the  Government  that 
increasing the capacity and efficiency of public transport would greatly benefit sustainable 
development. A new policy framework and measures are required to strengthen the public 
transport sector because road expansion alone is not a panacea bringing efficient and reliable 
transport. 
 
10.  Highway freight traffic is increasing at almost the same rate as GDP growth, or about 
10% per annum from 2003 to 2005. The total length of the expressway network increased from 
by 15% from 2003 to 2004 and by 20% from 2004 to 2005, during which time the total length of 
roads other than expressways increased by just 5% annually. Freight transport, especially inter-
province  and  international  traffic,  relies  heavily  on  the  expressway  network,  but  total  road 
investment has lagged behind the growth of freight transport. As noted above, logistical costs 
(transport, warehousing, administration, and inventory) are thought to account for 30–40% of

3
total cost of manufactured goods in the PRC, much more than the 5–20% in the United States. 
The share of land transport in the PRC is about 65% of the total cost of shipping a container 
from Chongqing to US West Coast. It is clear that expanding expressways is not the answer to 
ensuring efficient and reliable freight transport and that a new policy framework and measures 
are required, as they are for public transport. 
 
11.  The price of oil was $20 per barrel in January 2002 but rose to $72 per barrel in August 
2006, an increase of 360% in 2.5 years. Vehicle ownership in the PRC was about 1 million in 
the early 1990s but will reach 170 million by 2020. The number of vehicles is one indicator of oil 
consumption, and oil consumption is a direct indicator of GHG emissions. Without an adequate 
policy framework and necessary measures to promote energy efficiency and environmental 
conservation, it is clear that transport in the PRC threatens global energy security and harms 
the environment, both locally and globally. Also worth noting is that, as the PRC is the world’s 
second largest oil consumer, energy efficiency and environmental protection are concerns of 
both  national  and  global  relevance.  Improving  fuel  efficiency  in  transport  benefits  other 
countries’ sustainable development. Road traffic volume (vehicle-kms) in Japan, for example, 
increased by 7% from 1997 to 2003, but total CO  emissions fell by 3.3% in the same period 
2
(emissions from road transport accounts for about 20% of total CO  emissions). Half of the CO  
2 2
reduction  came  from  improved  vehicle  quality  and  the  other  half  from  improved  road 
infrastructure  and  traffic  management.  This  shows  the  potential  for  aligning  sustainable 
development  with  energy  and  environmental  issues  and  the  importance  of  systematic 
coordination between road administration and vehicle administration. 
 
12.  Under the 11FYP, the Government envisages significantly more efficient utilization of 
resources in all fields including the transport sector. The resource optimization targets of the 
11FYP in the transport sector are a (i) 20% reduction in land utilization per 100 million vehicle-
kms; (ii) 25% reduction in port berth occupancy per 10,000 tons throughput; (iii) 20% reduction 
in  energy  consumption  per  ton-km  of  vehicles  and  ships;  and  (iv)  20%  reduction  in  total 
emissions of major pollutants. To meet the 11FYP targets, effective policy and measures are 
needed to ensure sustainable, harmonious, and environmentally friendly development in the 
transport sector, which will continue to contribute to rapid economic development in the country. 
A holistic approach is needed, and the aspects the policy and measures should cover are 
technology, regulations, economics, and building public awareness.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The impact of TA is expected to be resource optimization on PRC roads. The outcome 
of TA will be a policy framework, measures, and guidelines for road planning and land use, road 
transport management, and improving energy efficiency and environmental protection. This will 
be  achieved  by  (i)  undertaking  a  detailed  assessment  of  the  current  state  of  resource 
optimization in the road sector, in particular focusing on road planning and land use, road 
transport management, and energy efficiency and environmental protection; (ii) identifying key 
issues relating to resource optimization in line with Government priorities in the 11FYP; (iii) 
learning from experience in developed countries where resource optimization is successfully 
implemented;  (iv)  preparing  recommendations  on  the  policy  framework  and  measures;  (v)

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  International experts and national consultants will be engaged to help the Government 
study resource optimization in the road sector for road planning and land use, road transport 
management, and energy efficiency and environmental protection. They will also prepare the 
policy framework and measures and develop the guidelines. TA will be undertaken in close 
consultation with provincial governments and the central Government agencies concerned and 
will take into account all previous studies carried out by the Government, ADB, and other 
multilateral agencies, as well as best international practice. TA will involve fieldwork, gathering 
international  experience,  analytical  research,  stakeholder  consultations  with  national  and 
provincial governments, agencies responsible for road transport and road users, and training for 
building the capacity of government staff to implement TA outputs.  
 
15.  TA will include case studies from selected provinces that exemplify typical issues in the 
PRC with regard to the three fields of road planning and land use, road transport management, 
and energy efficiency and environmental protection and are willing to solve the issues. The 
selected provinces should be cooperative and have sufficient information and data for their 
particular case study. The case studies will entail in-depth study on the current state and key 
issues in the three fields. The case studies will also apply the recommended policy framework, 
measures and guidelines.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The total cost of TA is estimated at $500,000. TA will be financed as a grant from ADB’s 
TA funding program. The Government requested ADB to finance $400,000. MOC will finance 
the remaining $100,000, which will cover office accommodation and counterpart staff required to 
implement TA. The detailed cost estimate is in Appendix 2.    
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  TA, including fieldwork, will require about 36 person-months of consulting services (6 
international and 30 national) spread over 9 months. Individual international consultants and a 
national consulting firm will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2006) and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of national 
consultants. The national consulting firm will be engaged following the quality-based selection 
method,  using  a  simplified  technical  proposal.  The  international  consultants  will  provide 
expertise in (i) road planning and land use, (ii) road transport management, and (iii) energy 
efficiency and environmental protection. The national consultants will have expertise in (i) road 
design and planning; (ii) planning and regulations on land use; (iii) road transport management; 
(iv) freight and public transport; (v) energy conservation in road transport, including vehicle 
standards; (vi) environmental economy and policy analysis on road transport, including GHG 
and vehicle emission control; and (vii) managerial skills. The national consultant providing 
managerial skills will be the team leader, and three international consultants will be the sub-
team  leaders.  The  international  experts  will  supervise  and  provide  their  inputs  to  each 
component.  A  national  consultant  firm  will  work  on  the  three  components  and  will  take 
responsibility  for  coordinating  the  entire  study.  Appendix  3  presents  an  outline  terms  of 
reference for the consultants.

5
18.  MOC will be the EA and therefore responsible for guiding and supervising TA activities 
and for coordinating with relevant government agencies and organizations. MOC will (i) ensure 
the  cooperation  of  the  government  agencies  concerned  and  (ii)  provide  guidance  and 
assistance to the consultants in implementing TA. To strengthen institutional capacity, TA will 
finance a domestic and overseas training program in the areas of road planning and land use, 
road  transport  management,  and  energy  efficiency  and  environmental  protection.  TA  is 
expected to commence in May 2007 and be completed by January 2008. The international and 
national  consultants  will  also  conduct  workshops  for  consultation  with  stakeholders and 
dissemination. MOC will provide to the consultants all relevant materials, recent studies, and 
reports required for TA. The consultants will maintain in close contact with MOC and ADB and 
will keep them informed of TA progress and findings. Tripartite meetings of the Government, 
ADB staff, and the consultants will be held to provide comments on a draft final report and guide 
the consultants in finalizing it. Procurement of equipment provided under TA will be carried out 
in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2006), and the equipment will be handed 
over to MOC upon completion of TA.  
 
19.  The consultants will submit the following reports to ADB and MOC as scheduled in the 
design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1): (i) a list of sources of information, a list of 
related regulations, a list of related organizations and contact persons, and an outline of case 
studies; (ii) a list of identified issues and potential recommendations (the policy framework, 
measures, and guidelines); (iii) an inception report, including an outline of the final report, 4 
weeks  following  commencement  of  the  services;  (iv)  an  interim  report;  (v)  draft 
recommendations of the policy framework and measures; (vi) recommendations of the policy 
framework and measures; (vii) the draft final report; (viii) guidelines for local government; and 
(ix) the final report 2 weeks after receiving all comments from MOC and ADB. In addition, the 
consultant will provide monthly progress reports to MOC and ADB. The consultants will hold a 
stakeholder consultation workshop within 8 weeks of commencing services and, within 4 weeks 
of submission of the draft final report, a national workshop in Beijing to disseminate TA findings. 
The inception report, interim report, draft final report, and final report will be submitted in English 
and  Chinese  to  ADB,  MOC,  Ministry  of  Finance,  and  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Resource Optimization in the Road 
Sector, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Road  Planning  and  Land  Use  (2.0 person-months international/9.0 person-months 
national) 
 
1.  An international consultant for road planning and land use, and national consultants for 
(i) road design and planning and (ii) planning and regulations for land use, will carry out the 
following tasks: 
(i)  Identify current cases of inefficient land use in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC), including but not limited to (a) decreased productivity of farmland; (b) lost 
opportunity for other development; (c) decreased efficiency of economic and social 
activities; (d) right of way larger than necessary; (e) inefficient layout of workplaces; 
(f) improper restoration of temporary work places; and (g) improper maintenance of 
roads (not only road surface but other structures like drainage and embankments). 
(ii)  Identify key issues causing inefficient land use in all phases (planning, including 
decision-making  processes  and  public-involvement  processes;  design; 
implementation; operation; and management) and regarding all related regulations, 
standards, life-cycle cost and unwritten rules of the road sector. 
(iii)  Identify issues regarding, for example, processes and measures of coordination 
between (a) land-use planning and regulations and (b) transport planning and 
regulations. (It has been pointed out that the former have been even weaker than 
latter, and it is commonly the lowest-income groups, including farmers, whose 
accessibility, mobility, safety, and security have suffered the most.) 
(iv)  To  address  the  issues  above,  survey  and  analyze  the  policy  framework, 
regulations,  standards,  and  measures  for  efficient  land  use  in  developed 
countries and identify good practice in developed countries for efficient land-use 
and measures adaptable to the PRC. 
(v)  Prepare recommendations in the form of a policy reform framework and necessary 
measures  to  enable  the  Government  to  proceed  with  implementation.  The 
recommendations should cover technological, economic, and regulatory aspects. 
(vi)  Prepare  guidelines  based  on  recommendations  for  local  government,  which 
should not be a simple list of general rules and advice but should be user-friendly 
tools, e.g., including sufficient examples of good practices and bad practices. 
(vii)  Select the model province that faces issues typical of the PRC with regard to 
road planning and land use and is willing to solve them. 
(viii)  Carry out a case study, including an in-depth analysis of the current state of 
affairs and issues; applying the recommended policy framework, measures, and 
guidelines  to  the  issues;  analyzing  an  approach  to  implement  the 
recommendations;  necessary  reform  and  actions;  possible  measures  to  be 
applied; the effects of recommendations; and a proposed action plan. 
(ix)  Amend the policy framework, measures, and guidelines based on the result of the 
case study, if necessary. 
(x)  Carry out a workshop to consult stakeholders at the beginning of the technical 
assistance (TA) and another workshop to disseminate the outputs and increase 
capability and awareness.

(i)  Survey and analyze the current status of freight and public transport in the road 
sector, including but not limited to (a) statistics and features of freight and public 
transport  in  the  PRC;  (b)  statistical  data  on  vehicles  for  freight  and  public 
transport; (c) statistical data and the current status of relevant organizations and 
their  operation  in  the  PRC;  (d)  the  status  of  international  freight  and  public 
transport; (e) the status of border-crossing transport for freight and passengers 
and border-crossing systems; (f) the status of public transport services provided 
to rural and isolated areas; (g) regulations on freight and public transport and 
related institutions, including operational regulations, licensing, inspection, and 
regulations regarding vehicles, the environment, safety, and pricing; (h) reliability 
and safety, including traffic accidents and overloading; (i) efficiency, productivity, 
and competition in freight and public transport; (j) the status of implementation 
and  impact  of  the  2004  Road  Transport  Ordinance  and  fact  finding  after 
implementation;  (k)  other  implemented  policy  reforms  and  the  effects  of  the 
reforms; (l) the status of infrastructure provided by the public sector to support 
freight and public transport, including roads, terminals, bus stops, databases, and 
other necessary information; (m) the status of infrastructure provided by the 
private sector to support freight and public transport, including terminals, truck 
plazas, maintenance workshops, and repair services; (n) major support from the 
public sector and the effects of the support; (o) taxes, fees, and tolls charged to 
freight  and  public  transport  operators;  (p)  gaps  in  national  and  international 
standards of freight transport; (q) users of freight and public transport and their 
demands;  (r)  coordination  between  demand  and  service  provision  and  its 
efficiency;  (s)  relations  with  users  and  the  feedback  system  from  users;  (t) 
anticipated demand for freight and public transport and the provision of services; 
(u) the status of applying information technology and other advanced technology; 
and (v) monitoring and inspection. The survey and analysis should cover both 
intercity transport and transport within cities. 
(ii)  Identify issues causing inefficiency in freight and public transport. 
(iii)  To  address  the  issues  above,  survey  and  analyze  the  policy  framework, 
regulations, standards, and measures for efficient road transport management in 
developed countries and identify good practices in developed countries for efficient 
road transport management that are adaptable to the PRC. 
(iv)  Discuss  the  feasibility  of  introducing  information  technology  and  other  new 
applicable technologies to increase operational efficiency. 
(v)  Prepare recommendations in the form of a policy reform framework and necessary 
measures  to  enable  the  Government  to  proceed  with  implementation.  The 
recommendations should cover technological, economic, and regulatory aspects. 
(vi)  Prepare guidelines based on the recommendations for local government. The 
guidelines should not be a simple list of general rules and advice but should be 
user-friendly tools, e.g. including sufficient examples of good practices. 
(vii)  Select the model province that faces issues typical of the PRC with regard to the 
road transport management and is willing to solve them. 
(viii)  Carry out a case study, including an in-depth analysis of the current state of 
affairs and issues; applying the recommended policy framework, measures, and 
guidelines  to  the  issues;  analyzing  an  approach  to  implement  the 
recommendations;  necessary  reform  and  actions;  possible  measures  to  be 
applied; the effects of recommendations; and a proposed action plan. 
(ix)  Amend the policy framework, measures, and guidelines based on the result of the 
case study, if necessary.

person-months national)  
 
3.  An  international  consultant  for  energy  efficiency  and  environmental  protection,  and 
national consultants for (i) energy conservation in road transport, including vehicle standards, 
and (ii) environmental economy and policy analysis in road transport, including greenhouse gas 
(GHG) and vehicle emission control, will carry out the following tasks:  
(i)  Review the current status of GHG emissions globally, including the policy and the 
progress  of  the  Conference  of  Parties  to  the  United  Nations  Framework 
Convention on Climate Change. 
(ii)  Survey  and  analyze  the  current  status  of  GHG  emissions  and  energy 
consumption in road transport in the PRC. Analyze the future prospects for GHG 
emissions and the energy consumption in the PRC. 
(iii)  Review and identify issues regarding GHG emissions and energy consumption, 
including but not limited to (a) existing data and statistics and data-collection 
systems and mechanisms; (b) existing research and analytical skills regarding 
GHG  emissions  and  energy  consumption  in  the  road  sector;  (c)  a  policy 
framework for GHG emissions and energy consumption; (d) regulations related 
to  environment  protection,  including  the  Environmental  Protection  Law, 
Environmental Impact Assessment Law, Radioactive Pollution Prevention Law, 
Air Pollution Prevention Law, and Environmental Noise Pollution Prevention Law; 
(e) the implementation of environmental monitoring; (f) technological, economic, 
and regulatory actions and measures taken by the Government; (g) mechanisms 
of impact analysis for road construction and the management of the analysis; (h) 
vehicle standards and existing vehicle quality with regard to emissions; and (i) 
the prospects for reducing GHG emissions and energy consumption through 
road investment and management. 
(iv)  To  address  the  issues  above,  survey  and  analyze  the  policy  framework, 
regulations, standards, and measures on energy efficiency and environmental 
protection  in  developed  countries  and  identify  good  practices  in  developed 
countries for energy efficiency and environmental protection that are adaptable to 
the PRC. 
(v)  Prepare recommendations in the form of a policy reform framework and necessary 
measures  to  enable  the  Government  to  proceed  with  implementation.  The 
recommendations should cover technological, economic, and regulatory aspects. 
(vi)  Prepare recommendations on land use and road transport management from the

(i)  Supervise the three components of TA, including providing support for acquiring 
the necessary information and data; coordinating with provincial governments,
